Expectation1: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation1: The deadline for closing the books for the month is approaching.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I glance at the clock on my phone, anxiety prickling at my skin. The deadline for closing the books is tonight, and I still have two accounts to reconcile. As an accountant, accuracy is everything—one mistake, and the whole report could be off. But here I am, standing in a long line at the polling station, laptop in my bag, spreadsheets swirling in my mind. Suddenly, an official calls out, “Voters with last names A–M, please move to the new line!” My last name starts with B. The new line is longer, barely moving, but the official’s voice is firm. I know I’m supposed to follow instructions, but every minute here is a minute lost from my work. My boss expects the books to be perfect and on time. The election officials expect me to comply without question. I feel torn, my sense of duty to my job clashing with my responsibility as a voter. My heart pounds as I weigh the pressure of both roles, caught between the rules of the polling place and the ticking clock of my professional life.
